Turns out that was not what the hotel offered.
So, I will now have to dispute those charges since the connection was bad and I did not get access at all except for the first few mins it needed the credit card number.
The beds were very comfortable, the toilet paper felt like sandpaper :)The location was unbeatable.
It was in the middle of the tourist section.
After I saw where the Crowne Plaza and Marriott was located, I was glad I won the Red Leeow bid, since we like being in the center of touristy things and this was it.
The RDL was literally a block away, we could be there in about 5 mins.
Loved Extase coffee shop, people in Amsterdam were so so friendly I cant begin to say enough!
Remember to buy water from the supermarket near Madame Tussauds, much cheaper than anywhere else.
We were charged city taxes of 5.66 euros per night per room.
Room service was quick and efficient.

Only once did we come back and see that housekeeping had kept a bag of trash on the bathroom sink and had forgotten to remove it, however someone came up in seconds after I called the front desk and had it cleared and kept on aplogizing.
There was an electric kettle in the rooms with cups, coffees, teas, sugar and creamer.
The only thing I did not like was the absence of an iron in the room.
I was told we would need to go to the ironing room on the third floor to iron...which felt wierd.
We also asked if we could keep one room till about 1pm and check out from the other two rooms since our flight was at 5pm and we were planning to leave the hotel around 2pm.

The desk agent was very quick to say no and it was abrupt, if the other agents had not been nice I would have had a problem with it.Anyway, it was a good hotel, not to be compared to a 4 star in the US but good...I would recommend the hotel but remember it might be a good idea to take the upgrade if offered and it is reasonable.

author: hcb10960
segments: great experience except... ...for the concierge problem.
More on that later.
We actually stayed at this W twice in ten days.
Our stays bookended a trip to SF.When we first arrived the cab dropped us at the restaurant entrance not the main entrance.
When we got to the bottom of the staircase leading to check-in the bellman could not have been nicer.
He got an extra guy to help with all of our gear.
Both check ins were smooth, staff lovely, room was great.
The second check-in was particularly nice, as one of the young ladies behind the desk made a special point to welcome my son back to the hotel with a high five and It's great to see you again.
Went a long way.
We had a view of Mt. Rainier the first leg, lower down the second.
Room service during both stays was excellent.
The lobby was lovely to hang out in, the restaurant was very, very good.
To the concierge problem...we dealt with three concierges during our stays.
Two of which were fine, one simply didn't do his job or meet our requests.
First, he was on his cell phone at the concierge desk and seemed annoyed that we interrupted him.
We wanted to make dinner reservations for two nights and asked whether we needed reservations for a third restaurant.
It was early in the day, he said the first two would not be open, but would make the reservations later and noted it on the computer.
He then said we did not need reservations at the third.
That was that, thanks!,
and we were on our way.Later that evening, we arrived at the 'no reservation' restaurant to discover a two hour wait for a table of three and Oh no, we ALWAYS recommend reservations.
Hmmm, basic info a concierge should know.
We walked back to the hotel to check on the other reservations with the evening concierge.
Neither had been made.
He was very apologetic and expressed that this had been a problem for a number of guests that day.
He took care of the reservations and found us another place to eat that evening.
Despite the intitial problem, it was dealt with in a more than satisfactory way and we would absolutely stay there again.

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: A great value in a prime location
We were staying at the Pan Pacific for our anniversary and booked our trip through priceline.
According to the Pan Pacific's rates, the cheapest room in the place is $340 per night, but we found a great all-inclusive deal that averaged out to about $100 per night.
The service was above average, but not as excellent as all of the reviews that I had read.
The staff was friendly and helpful, especially at the concierge desk.
After a long travel day, our room wasn't ready when we arrived, and it took a little prompting on my part to speed up the process - which I shouldn't have to do.
Everything else was extremely positive after that, though.
The concierge was very helpful in booking us a rental car.
The room was very clean and nicely decorated.
It's not a huge room, but we weren't in our room very often anyways.

Another note about the room - the street noise is pretty loud at times; I woke to the sounds of bottles being dumped into a bin from the lounge across the street and the ambulance/police sirens a few times as the windows are single-paned and don't keep out sound very well.
The workout room on the 5th floor was nice, and it seemed to be getting regular use from the hotel guests.
It was maintained very well.
We didn't eat at the restaurant, and it didn't look as though it received a lot of business.
The menu looked great, but was pricey.
Housecleaning was fantastic!
They really did a nice job each day on our room.
The Pan Pacific is convenient for getting on the bus line and trolley lines.
Most lines were 1-3 blocks away.
Finally, I liked the 3rd floor lobby.
It was a good choice for placing the lobby, as we didn't have to walk through crowds to get to our room.
We could just bypass all of that with the elevator.
By the way - the glass elevators are a nice touch!
We will definitely stay at the Pan Pacific again.
We encountered many other tourists at different SF sights asking us where we were staying, and they said that we were lucky to be there because of the reputation of the place.
Plus, many others weren't enamored with their accomodations.
That felt good to know that on our first trip, we hit it on the mark with our hotel choice!

author: shatiyask
segments: Never Again!
I booked a room at the
Elpalacio for my vacation as a getaway, big mistake.
Problem #1, the remote control for the television did not work.
They finally responded to the problem 3 hours later and offered to switch my room, which was not an opinion because I had already unpacked.
Problem #2 when I went to turn on the AC I noticed that there where ants crawling on top of the unit.
Problem #3 At about 9:45am housekeeper enter my room while I was in bed.
When she noticed I was there she ran out of the room.
I recieved a knock at my door around 11:00am by another housekeeping to clean the room.
I then asked the housekeeper if she could give me 5 minutes, because I was on my way out and she said yes.

When I exited the room, she appeared to be entering the room to clean, but when I returned at 2:30pm the room was still in the same condition which made me angry because I had returned to the room to rest.
I immediately came out and approached another housekeeper, who informed that she was sending someone right away.
I waited for another 45 minutes, still no one.
I then went to the front desk where a gentleman gave me, the guest, directions to housekeeping so that I could inquire on my behalf because he was too busy on the phone.
He should have been the one to resolve the matter.
Finally the housekeeper returned to the room to give fresh towels and empty the garbage pails, were left empy.
She left a roll of gabage bags on the bathroom sink, I guess that was for me to do.Overall, I did not care for the service that I recieved.
The room had an odor ( it's a good thing I brought the febreeze), and next time I think I'll spend the extra money and get something decent because this hotel was far from it.

author: upstategal_8
segments: Great hotel Hotel was conveniently located steps from a subway station and key bus routes.
Desk staff was friendly and very helpful at booking tours and providing directions.
Only downside was lack of air conditioning in rooms, but in May, it was fine and could open windows to let cool air in when it got warm.
Breakfast had a lot of variety and was very good! Would definitely stay there again!

author: Joots
segments: Great Place We stayed here for 4 nights, and the experience was excellent.
For euro hotels the room was spacious and kept to a high standard.
Only minor point was that they are strict about no ironing in the room and no in room tea/coffee in normal double rooms.
However if you are travelling with a laptop they provide free internet in the rooms (decent speed ~2mbps) ask at reception for pass code.
Its less than a 5min walk from the station, so is a perfect base for visiting florence and surrounding towns/cities.
The italian train system is cheap and v.reliable.
While there we visitied places like Pisa (1hr) and Viareggio (beaches 1hr 20mins) by train.
Also the staff are very friendly and it is based near a variety of restaurants/bars and clubs.

author: BunkoRT
segments: Great location, rooms questionable
My husband and I stayed here during a conference last week and it was alright.
The concierge was very informative and the front staff very polite.
The room cleaning was questionable though as they did not remove empty water bottles the whole time we stayed.
They also only dumped the garbage, they did not replace the lining.
I think that towels were just refolded and replaced instead of giving new towels.
The showers were actually very small although there was excellent pressure from the showerhead.
We didn't dine at the hotel, although we heard firsthand that there was one restaurant that was very slow in service (main course took 2 hours).
The location of this hotel was good, the subway station was not too far away.
If I had to go to Boston again, I may look elsewhere to stay.

author: Kearnz
segments: Good hotel Me and three other people stayed at this hotel in early
August 2006.
We arrived in our car after a long journey from Las Vegas, and we were very tired.
After we arrived, the bell men took our luggage into the hotel, and our car was parked for us.
We had requested connecting rooms when we booked and there were no problems at all with this.
We have stayed in numerous hotels before and more than half did not give us connecting rooms.
We went up to the rooms.
The rooms were slightly outdated, with stripy coloured wall-paper, and country style curtains.
Yet, the rooms had a balcony, plus the bed was a tempur one.
Since we were tired, we ordered rooms service.
The menu was pretty good with a choice of steaks, pizzas, pastas and salads.
The meal arrived in about 35 minutes and was v.good.
The hotel is located about 15-20 minutes from central Hollywood, and is right in the center of Beverly Hills, on Beverwil Drive.
Staff were friendly, and service was excellent.
Breakfast wasn't to good, and the rooms could do with some updating.
Overall, it was a really good hotel.

author: sdmooreNorthCarolina
segments: Great place to stay!
I was very happy with our stay here.
Even with the weak dollar, I thought it was a great value.

author: MeridianManchester
segments: Brilliant Berlin base
We stayed 4 nights here on a first visit to Berlin.
We had a family suite for 3 adults - it was huge, comfortable and clean.
It's in a good position to see the sites of old East Berlin and close to public transport to go further afield.
The only meal is breakfast and we tended to go out for that - cheaper!
There are good coffee bars and restaurants nearby.
There is a small bar and the staff are very friendly and helpful.

author: wowzer
segments: Nice upper end place
Very nice hotel, but rooms are small and area is newer live/work type.
Be sure to get the larger room and have breakfast included as it is $25 if you pay.
Nice food due to the French Chef on staff, but pricey.
Doesn't feel like Japan hotel, more like a contemporary Hilton.
If you want to feel the city vibes and eat close by at more authentic restaurants, don't stay here.
If you want out of the hustle more modern surroundings, this is your place.

author: milhouse
segments: Nothing Exciting Stayed here for one night before moving over to The Phoenician.
While not bad, it certainly lacks many of the finer qualities of the area's better establishments (Four Seasons, Phoenician, Fairmont Scottsdale Princess).
Located in a so so area of North Phoenix.
The room itself had a popcorn ceiling and poorly textured walls.
It struck me that if 6 Motel ever decided they wanted to go resort style this would be the place that they would open up.
The comforter and bedding, as well as the entire interior, were all standard Hilton - nothing to connote the southwest (the comforter was a loudy itchy green floral print).
The wash basin was also located in the bedroom (not in the bathroom) which struck me as odd and does not help matters when one person is an earlier riser than another.
View = My wife and I were given a view which overlooked a parking lot and other peoples balconies.
It's a good 20 minute drive to the center of Scottsdale (if you're looking to dine at one of the many fine dining spots in the Scottsdale area).
While not bad for families looking to save a little, it is not the luxurious resort for which it bills itself.
And it is far, very far, from being even one of the top 5-6 resorts in the area.

author: jbirish1
segments: A Fantastic Experience...
February 20, 2007Fantastic Place...My wife and I spent the last week at the Iberostar Bavaro Punta Cana.
The weather was really tropical and sunny.
It was in the mid-80's during the day and the 70's at night.
Perfect-especially considering it was 8 at home in Michigan.
The best resort experience we have ever had.What we really liked...1.
The suites were neat and well maintained.
We read about a musty smell in the rooms.
We were able to eliminate this by opening the patio doors for a couple of hours each day and by keeping the lid closed on the toilet.
The grounds were beatiful and at night the ground lighting created a romantic effect in the landscaping.
It was quiet and peaceful almost all of the time.
Not many loud drinking parties.
The staff was friendly and energetic.
They performed task with a positive attitude.
We often observed them singing to the background music.
They were not intrusive or or patronizing.
They carried themselves with dignity and were appreciative of tips-while not acting as though they expected to be tipped.
The beach had numerous palm thatched cabana's.
We able to reserve one every day.
We spent most of the day on the beach.
You could be in the sun or in the shade.
The water was a tropical blue with darker shading over the coral reefs.
There was constant activity on the beach and just off shore.
People constantly walked the beach-about 10% of the women are topless.
There are power boats, sail boats para sails up and down the beach.
The snorkeling in front of the Bavaro was very good and snorkel equipment was free for one hour each day.
Yellow tail snapper (some a foot long) and barracuda, sargeant fish, and tripletail were within 200 feet of the beach.
We are in our 50's and enjoyed the contact with the families with young children.
The parents and the children were well mannered.
The staff does a nice job entertaining the children.
Every night the kids were involved in putting on little shows.
The food was generally of good quality-but not necessarily geared to American tastes.
You had to pick and chose.
We liked the grilled foods the best- chicken, lobster, steak and the chips and salsa.
On Wednesday night, they serve lobster at the buffet.
Choose to go to the specialty resturants on other nights.
We liked the Japenese and the Steakhouse the best.
Most of the drinks were rum drinks, but you could get other types of drinks on request.
Tipping always helpsThe Bavaro appeared to be much more upscale than the other two Iberostar properties

author: benz22
segments: "Not professional management"
I stayed at the RIU the last time I visited Miami.
While there, a hurricane came through.
Because of the large amounts of water, my room flooded, as did many others.
My room was on the top floor and the ceiling leaked badly.
The hotel was sold out and I could not move to another room.
They did have one room available, but it was leaking as well.I spoke to the manager, Joanna Turmo, about my room.
She offered to, take care of my parking during my stay.

She also told me to call her the next time I was visiting Miami and that she would,take care of me.Although my room was damaged(ceiling leaking and carpet flooded) I agreed with the offer and continued my stay at the hotel.
Here is my problem: I do realize that they had no control over the heavy rains from the hurricane, I have no problems with that.
However, what makes me angry is that when I try to contact the manager, Joanna Turmo, she will not take my calls, or return my calls.
As I said earlier, she offered to, take care of me, the next time I visited Miami.
So, if you ever have a bad experience at this hotel and they promise you something, you better get it in writing because Joanna Turmo will not come to the phone.
The staff will tell you she is in a meeting or is not in the hotel.I have tried to call Joanna on two occassions that I visited/planned to visit Miami.

author: Paulip
segments: Not worth the reputation
I am now staying in the hotel and I have a lot of dissatisfaction about the hotel.I am living in the deluxe room and it is facing to the office directly.
The staff said I need to pay at least 5000 yens to change to another deluxe room for better view.
There is a lot of high tech inside the room but some is just too high tech and not useful and even dangerous.
They used Lavazza coffee cooker to provide the hot water, which is very dangerous.
I know how to Assembly a computer and write web page , but I don't know how to get hot water safely.
I cannot stop the hot water coming out from the machine.
There is no fruit complementary despite some website say it is provided.
If you have been living in Hong kong peninsula you know it is totally different thing.
The cafe downstairs is terrible, decoration is bad and smelly.
Bacon is not deep fired.I resend to choose Tokyo Peninsula for my Christmas Holiday .But I will highly recommend Tokyo Hong Kong which I had my wedding in this hotel many years ago.

author: angusScotland
segments: Great Hotel The first thing you see coming down the steps of the station at
Ferrovia is the Grand Canal.
the second thing, just over the bridge, is the Hotel Antiche Figure, and what a welcome sight!
The location is perfect for bus and train station,and the water buses are right there.
We found the staff at the hotel charming and helpful, and the accommodation very good.
The recommended local restaurants were excellent.
No better place to stay in Venice.

author: DCitalophile
segments: A good value, with a few kinks
We stayed at the Palladium Grand Bavaro.
The hotels grounds are immaculate.
The room (a Romance Suite) was very spacious and near both the beach and pool.
One of the highlights was the staff: they were great, from the groundskeepers to the maids to the bar and wait staff.
We booked through Apple Vacations and their staff was competent and helpful.
Apple had 2 reps on duty in the hotel lobby and, since they spoke excellent English, they could help us with some of the kinks we had with the hotel.
More on this below.
Positives: very clean, incredible beach, ample bars and watering holes all around the campus, excellent athletic facilities, and again cannot overemphasize the friendly staff.
I would recommend this place, but arm yourself with good information from people who have stayed there before.
On your way in, grab one of the oodles of people checking out and get their advice.
I think the pitfalls I discuss below could be avoided if you know what you're up against from the outset.
Rooms in punta cana don't really have views.
Beaches are monopolized by beach huts and restaurants, so don't expect a room right on the water.
This surprised me.Also, very family friendly: so if you want a quiet, adults-only vacation, consider a resort specifically for that preference.
No snorkeling right on the hotel's beach (too many waves and no reef), so you have to book a separate excursion.
Hotel extremely clean and everything extremely well manicured.
Wouldn't recommend horse back riding in Punta Cana, as horses are malnourished and are not what you would be used to.
(Hotel does not have horses, you would book this separately).
Expect, as with all beach hotels in Punta Cana, people to solicit you frequenty on the beach for tourism trips and excursions, etc.
This can get rather annoying, but the people are friendly enough).
Tip: if you want a beach chair at the beach or pool, go there before 9am or so and put your magazine or towel on your chair.
There aren't enough to go around!
The more frustrating kink was the hotel's dinner reservation system.
At check in, we were given 2 dinner reservation tickets for reservations in one of the Fiesta resorts' many alla carte restaurants (vs. the large buffets where reservations are not necessary).
We were told to make the reservation at the Customer Relations desk.
First, the line to make reservations was long (wait time ranged from 10-25 mins).
When we finally got to talk to the Customer Relations representatives (not very experienced ), they flipped through the book for each restaurant and told us that all slots were taken.
They put us on the wait list, which looked really long.
We ended up getting a reservation at La Uva, for Wed night at 6pm (oh well), but we did not get another reservation the rest of the week.
At first, we were worried, since we were not impressed by the large buffet at the Grand Palladium.
We were relieved to discvover that the buffet at the Palace was much better - excellent really.
So we enjoyed 3 excellent meals, however only one of them was at one of the promised alla carte restaurants.
However, exceedingly frustrating was that the alla carte restaurants were never more than 35 percent full, that we saw, during any dinner time.

This means that the hotel wasdeliberately limiting the number of available reservations at the more intimate and more labor intensive alla carte restaurants, and in doing so were steering people to the much more cost efficient buffets.
We found the lack of available reservations, and the logistics of the reservation system in general (you don't find out if you have a dinner reservation until the afternoon - or evening! -
you are supposed to be dining there) to be very frustrating.
We thought it was really false advertising, since a diversity of restaurants was promised.
I tried to speak to a manager about this complaint, but was given the brush off.
I let it go since it was, afterall, our vacation and I did not feel like fighting with someone.

author: daxoz
segments: What an AMAZING resort!
My
Husband and I just returned from Bahia Principe after spending 1 week from May 19th-May 26th.
To sum up, the holiday from beginning to end was perfect.
The resort is a tropical paradise.

These are the best points:-well maintained grounds-amazing, friendly, helpful staff (our maid was incredible)-Perfect manicured beach-An abundance of chairs in the shade at the pools and beach (Could still get a chair at 9:30-10ish)-Food was very good and very vegetarian accomodating.
We were only able to eat at one of the a la cart's( The Italian) because the other ones did not have a non-vege option.
But the buffet was delicious and diverse enough to keep our palettes satisfied!-
We were not able to upgrade (we arrived at 8:30pm) and they said that all the upgrade rooms were booked, but in my opinion the regular booking suffised.
I didn't feel that I was treated any differently or missed out on anything.
They rate this resort as a 5 star, and it truly is.
We have been to Sandals Jamaica, Cuba and Cancun and this is by far the best we have visited.
Anyone visiting this hotel is sure to have an amazing time, we are going back with friends in October!Enjoy your trip and have a Banana Mama for me!

author: sputnik1
segments: Great resort!
We had a wonderful two week vacation at Riu Palace Macao.
This was our second time at this resort and we enjoyed iteven more than the first time!
The kids (7 years old) had a great time and are already asking when we are going to go back.
- Beach.
Never crowded and it has both sunny and shaded areas.
The shade is provided by the beautiful palm trees.
There is alway a breeze from the ocean, so it never feels too hot.

It is a perfect place to relax with a good book or have a nap.The waiter is always roaming around, so drinks are easy to get.There is a hut nearby where you can get massages, which both me and my wife took advantage of and enjoyed greatly.- Staff and service.
The staff is simply outstanding.
Everyone here seem to enjoy their work and it shows.
They are always smiling and try to make you feel special.
- Rooms.
We did not have any problems with AC or moist bedding that some people have complained about.
The AC worked fine and the room was very clean.

We asked for extra bedding sheets for the kids and they brought them right away, though the next day the maid took them away, and when we called to ask for them again, they brought a whole bed instead - talk about the language barrier!
We also asked for extra water (you have to use bottled water to drink and brush teeth) many times and it was always provided.- Entertainment.
There is mini disco that the kids really enjoyed.
Johny does an excellent job with Bingo, always drawing plenty of laughs from the audience.
We saw a couple of shows (International and Michael Jackson) and liked them.
- Food.
We ate mostly at the buffet.
There were plenty of choices and I especially enjoyed the seafood - calamari, grouper, salmon, shrimp, were really good.
The sparkling wine is really good and can become addictive.
I was having about 5 glasses per day toward the end of the second week.
I did not like the red or white wines.
The beer was good.

The deserts were excellent, make sure to try the stewed bananas: put a couple on top of some ice cream (you'll thank me later) Also, don't forget the fruits, the choices are mostly limited to whatever grows locally, but they taste much better then what we get here in Canada.
- We ate lunch at the Caribe Grill beach bar, couple times.
The view and breeze from the ocean makes this place really awesome.
Also, they offer burgers and hot dogs for lunch for those who need their fix of junk food.- Drinks.
I found most mixed drinks to be pretty bad.
If you enjoy a great Marguerita or a Pina Colada, sadly you are not gonna get it here.
Most drinks are made in kind of a big slushy machine, as opposed to a mixer.
The bartender just adds liquor to it and here you go.
That said, my wife and kids enjoyed virgin pina coladas very much.
Overall the vacation was excellent and we are definitely going to come back in the furture!

author: thriller_7
segments: Westin St Francis is a stunning hotel overall
I stayed for three nights at the Westin St Francis in the newer tower building.
As there were no twins available I had originally booked a standard double in the historic building but was shown to a standard queen room instead.
The room was beautiful, though small, and everything was neat and clean.
I had read reviews on this site that the older smaller rooms were dated and dirty but this was not the case at all.
I did however get an extremely strange feeling in the room, and was not keen to stay for a reason that is unknown to me!

We asked to be upgraded to the newer part of the hotel for an additional $35.00 per night, and as we left the old part of the hotel I mentioned to my sister that my right ear started ringing loudly as soon as we entered the room.
She said her right ear was also ringing in the historic room... very spooky!
Anyway, having upgraded to the tower room with two queen beds, we had absolutely no complaints.
The room was massive, and the bathroom was incredible!
The beds were heavenly as promised, and the dual shower was great too.
It was well worth the extra money for the upgrade.
The only thing even slightly disapointing was the view, (of some old buildings), but you can't have everything.
Staff were friendly and helpful and the public areas of the hotel are stunning.
I really enjoyed watching the documentary on the hotel tv channel about the history of the St Francis- fascinating!
I would definitely love to return to the St Francis in the future.

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: Lout's Stag 3/4
Jun 05 Not a bad hotel if you accept you get what you pay for.
Location is perfect for RLD, Teasers is a lively bar just down the road, also Tara (good Irish bar) further down on Rokin.
Beds were clean, towels changed each day, no sign of bed bugs (despite extensive searching on arrival).

Gets noisy in the morning with street cleaners so forget the lie in go to Barney's in Jordaan (Haarlemerstraaat) for breakfast instead, much more fun (can I have some more pancakes with extra maple syrup please).
Reception has safe deposit box if you need it.
No complaints, hotel served it's purpose admirably.
Be careful not to wander into attic late at night though as carpet is very damp.
Dobsxxx

author: daltonb
segments: Certainly Splendid !
We spent New Year's Eve in this wonderful Hotel.

We were able to watch the festivities from our room as we sipped champagne and celebrated the beginning of 2007.A marvellous hotel with the chief concierge, Farooq, being incredibly helpful and knowledgable.
He is an amazing source of information.
Just ask him and he has the answers !!We will return to this wonderful , splendid hotel soon !

author: Madbenjoel  <Content>Fnatatstic....but.
segments: I have to agree with most of the other reviews on this property.
The location is perfect, the staff are mostly fantastic.
There are some who seem to be just doing a job but this is compensated by the others who are the best.
The food and wine on level 2 is a great option and my kids loved being able to go down and snack.
The suite we had was great and the option of the fold out sofa made things better for the four of us.
My only negative is that the beds were too short.
I am only six foot one, so not overly tall, but my feet were always hanging over the end of the bed which is uncomfortable.
This is unusual and may be due to size of the rooms but for such a well thought out hotel, I thought this was a significant issue.
Despite this, I would stay at Casablanca again if I was lucky enough to come to New York.

author: LilyOhio
segments: Reviews are correct
We stayed only 1 night after a cruise with Carnival.
The hotel is great.
It is very clean and yet has the rustic appeal of the oldbusiness it used to be.
Many of the buildings in the French Quarter are very run down do to their age.
But this hotel wascompletely renovated in 2004 and remains well maintained.
We had a room facing Magazine street which had 18ft ceilings and windows to match - beautiful.
We were very close tothe French Quarter but in quiet area.
We also felt very safe.
We ate at Cafe du Monde, Johnny Poboys, and Mothers.
All very good - only don't expect to be waited on .
These areold time diners which have become famous for their food.
Cleanliness is not a priority in this area - so go with thatin mind.
Very glad we experienced New Orleans.
New Orleans is a must for every American.

author: conrad0928
segments: Had a great time
I was at the Iberostar Bavaro with friends and family.
Everyone we traveled with was 19 and older and I must say I am happy we chose the Bavaro.
Alot less young kids and most of the beach and crazy activities were next door at the dominican so basically our hotel was very relaxing.
Check in went smoothly.
Hector at the front desk was great.
Our rooms honestly were a bit smaller then I was expecting but very clean , nice and AC worked great.
The repfrom Go Go another Hector was also great.
We did Zip Lining which was great and the caribean festival catamaran.
We swam with sharks and sting rays.
If you are looking for a party boat, don't waste your money, if you want to experience the sharks and sting rays this is a good one if not try the all day snorkel, scuba and bbq one.
A few went on the ATVs and loved it, but a bit more dangerous.
We loved the beach Bar and julio mayo and Noe.
At night there is not much Adult entertainment.
The 19 year olds and the 22 yearolds went to the Star rock cafe at night.
They met alot of people there.
We went in early.
Very long days with scuba and excursions.
We ate mostly at the buffet that had great choices.
The steak house and japaneese restaurants were great.
Make your reservations as soon as you get there.
Make sure you bring plenty of sun tan lotion-very expensive in the gift shop.
Also bring comfy shoes, ALOT of walking, take advantage of the golf carts to bring you to the other hotels at night.
They will also drop you right off at your room if you ask.
Also it really doesn't matter where your room is located, each section has its benefits.
We were in 1317 upper unit, directly behind the beach bar, for us that was great.
If you are traveling with younger kids you might want your rooms closer to the Dominica for the pool and beach activities.
Also it was verrry HOT.
Don't go crazy worrying about fancy evening wear, pack as little as possible and bring a clip for the hair.
All the employees there could not have done more or been nicer.
Don't be afraid and Book now.One suggestion to the hotel.
Please build one lounge that has AC.
I like a nice glass of wine in the evening and would like a bit of AC with it.
(other then the casino bar a bit smokey for non smokers)

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: Wyndham - Great Location!
My husband and I just returned from a 4-day weekend in Boston and had a great time.
We stayed at the Boston Wyndham and found it was close to many of the attractions, especially Fanueil Hall/Quincy Market.
We took many of the reviewers' advice and signed up for the Wyndham By Request.
We were able to check-in at 10:30am when we arrived and later in the afternoon received our complimentary snack and drink.
The staff was very friendly and always willing to help with any questions.
The only thing we found that our room did not have were drawers to keep our clothes in, so we had to live out of our suitcases.
Other than that, our room was very clean and quiet.
Some suggestions for those going for a long weekend trip....Book the Beantown Trolley Tour.
It is the only 2-day tour you can get on and off the trolley at the different stops.
Buy your tickets at the Wharf, not the concierge - they only have 1-day passes.
We used this as our main transportation for the first two days and we saw basically everything without getting too overwhelmed.
Walking the Freedom Trail also helped.
If you go to Salem, take the Trolley Tour.
This gives you the basic idea of the city and you can get on and off the trolley.
You will have to take the train to get to Salem, too.
This was very easy and the concierge gave us train times and directions.
If you are looking for a few nice dinner restaurants, we loved Legal Seafood (at the Wharf) and Plaza III Kansas City Steakhouse (at Fanueil Hall/South Market).
Both were very good.
Plaza III is pricey, but well worth the money!
Also, if you are going during baseball season, you will have to buy a Red Sox hat, T-shirt, etc.
It is all over the city and you will defintely catch the fever!
Go to a game, too.
It was so much fun and there are plenty of bars around the park to go to before and after (Game On and Cask 'n Flagon were our favorites).

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: Superlative I was impressed by the service and the comfort that
I found at the Omni - and I will be the first to admit that I am hard to please : ).

This hotel had a knowledgeable, professional and friendly staff - their recommendations of a Chinese restaurant in nearby Chinatown or of a restaurant in close North Beach were spot-on when I made clear my price range and my expectations.
The rooms had an understated elegance to them and there was considerable attention to detail - including a starched linen cloth at the foot of the bed for the slippers - a nice touch indeed.

The location along the cable-car track put me at one end to Market Street and a connection near the top of Nob Hill brought me into either Union Square or Fisherman's Wharf in good time to enjoy the many things that San Francisco had to offer.
Yet, being far enough away from the hectic activity of these places -- especially during this time of year -- made the hotel room a welcome refuge.

Contrary to other reviews, I found the prices at both the restaurant and the lounge to be comparable and fair considering the location of the hotel in the Financial District and the level of service and quality provided.
However, as I stated earlier, there are ample restaurants nearby from which you can choose.
Finally, the use of a town car for a slightly higher fee than a taxi was an excellent touch.
I travelled with 3 others who had a number of bags - and a Cadillac Escalade was ready at my time of booking to take our group to the airport.
This truly is a superlative property.
For the rate, it has to be the best value and the best comfort in San Francisco.

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: Expectations!!!
I have been to a bunch of different resorts in DR, Mexico, St. Maarten, St.
Thomas, etc.
I have to comment to anyone who is thinking of going to a Caribbean Resort...YOUR VACATION IS AS GOOD OR BAD AS YOUR EXPECTATION.
If you think you are going to a American/Canadian 4-5 star resort you would be fooling yourself.

As many people have commented poorly about this resort and others, you need to remember you are not at home, most of the people who live in these countries do not have large homes with 2 cars, a pool etc.
Their entire family lives with them in a 500 sq ft house.
So the hard work, quality food, and other amenities they are providing are 10X higher than what they are used to receiving in their day to day lives.
Just thought I should mention this as I have stayed at 3 star, 4 star and 5 star hotels in the Dominican and the difference between them is minimal as far as the quality of food.
If you want Wolfgang Puck, you should stay home to get it.
But if you open your mind and realize you are experiencing how others live, you will love it.

author: GlobalTravelerBoston
segments: What a DUMP... there are much better accomodations for the same price
Stayed for one night at Casa Alta to do a bio tour.
This place was just disgusting.
If you must stay here check out the room first before you hand over your credit card.
I was first given room #1, very dark and damp, had a basement feel since it was on the ground floor half buried in dirt.
At first the check in person at the convenience store would not give me another room stating that everything was taken until we realized that the toilet was leaking into the bedroom.
At first he told us to just turn the water valve off on the back of the toilet.
When I threatened to leave to go to another place down the road he gave us another room on the upper floor.
It was not much better but at least the toilet didn鈥檛 leak and the sheets looked clean.
I was afraid to look under the mattress.
If it wasn鈥檛 so late at night and if I was staying more than one night I would have left.

author: HayJam
segments: Fantastic location Stayed at the
Inglaterra hotel for 3 nights in February, the hotel was in an excellent location just off La Rambla.
The hotel is a small boutique hotel that has been recently modernised.
The rooms are very clean and are the perfect base while exploring the city, ask for a room at the front of the hotel as you get your own personal little balcony.

The rooftop terrace offers a nice view of the city at sunset while enjoying a few evening drinks even in february! I would definately reccommend this hotel and will have no hesitation in staying here again!

author: summersail
segments: Value for the price
I have stayed here several times for business over the last couple of years.
They have nice meeting room space, and the rooms are reasonably priced.
The hotel is in a convenient location, walking distance to many areas.
The hotel is across from Victoria Park, which is great.
Many rooms have a harbor view.
The rooms are recently renovated, and much improved.
Very good internet access in the rooms, and wireless in areas of the hotel.
Room size is average.
Buffet breakfast is very extensive.
It was included in my room rate.
A very large variety of western and Chinese selections.
The lobby level has a coffee lounge that serves light snacks and is a nice gathering spot.
Good service overall.

author: Work_Frankfurt
segments: Terrible Behaviour, good breakfast
The hotel as such was good with a very good breakfast.
I stayed here along with a friend for more than 20 days and the behaviour of the guys at the reception was terrible.
As an instance, I went to ask him about reservation and he said We will talk tomorrow morning, Thanks you without even looking at me.
The rooms are small and there is no place to move but I guess it is ok for the price.
Connectivity from the hotel to all important places is good as it is right in front of the main station.

author: Waikiki-recent-guest
segments: A "Diamond in the Rough"
We stayed on a 25th floor Ocean View room.
The room was fine, but be forewarned, the neighboring Hilton is building a high-rise time share building right next to the Ilikai (Diamond Head side).
The construction noise was VERY loud.
We could not sit on our 25th floor balcony and enjoy the ocean views without the daytime sounds of ear-splitting, pile-driving machines and other construction equipment.
The Ilikai also permanently closed one of their two pools because the adjacent (Yacht Harbor) tower was sold to another company.
I hope they update their website to advise of this.
One last complaint; We had a $100.
00 Hotel restaurant and room service voucher.
If you receive this, please note: It is NOT APPLICABLE to Sarentos (roof-top-expensive-incredible views) Restaurant.
We learned this the hard way, after dining there- Front Desk Staff should have told us of this exclusion on day one but forgot (?).
We ultimately used our remaining balance at Canoe's Restaurant, and we were not disappointed- EXCELLENT restaurant (ask for an outdoor, tiki-lamp-lit table!).
Enjoy!
Ilikai recent guest

author: kenw83
segments: Nice hotel, great location The Luna
Simone is a great hotel near Victoria Station.
The hotel was clean and the staff was very friendly.
The rooms were average European size and the bathroom was very modern with plenty of hot water.
As mentioned in previous reviews, there is no lift.
So if you have trouble with stairs request a lower floor.
We slept in every day so we did not try the breakfast.
However, we did eat at several of the restaurants nearby and enjoyed all of them.
All things considered, the Luna Simone is a great hotel and we would stay there again.

author: Atown84  <Content>Ambassador... eh I stayed at the
segments: Ambassador recently with a couple friends.
The hotel itself is pretty nice.
The downstairs bar looked really nice.
The room we stayed in had some issues with the flooring, but the size and beds were not an issue.
We did have a BIG problem with a member of the night staff.
A buddy and I were out pretty late one night drinking and having a great time.
When we arrived back at the hotel we had to wait outside for about an hour and a half because the lady at the front desk did not buzz us in.
When we complained she said You were outside for about 5 minutes basically called us liars.
The hotel itself is a nice location and the rooms are ok but the staff sucks.

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: A Terrific San Francisco Choice
Just got back from a three-night stay at The Rex and it's only fair to sing this hotel's praises.

Location is great; the rooms are comfortable; the amenities (morning paper, free wine in the evening, high-speed internet) are perfectly lovely; the adjoining restaurant great for breakfast (I didn't eat dinner there, but it looked filled up when I stuck my head in); the New Yorker magazine theme in the lobby and the library fun.
But what really sets it apart is the attentive staff and the above-and-beyond level of service and helpfulness.
It's a hotel you can feel welcome and at home at--I'm convinced it's one of the best buys in San Francisco.

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: super!!
The Hotel
Aalders was an home coming experience!!!
Pleasant and helpfull staff.
.especially Alex...thank you for everything!!
The rooms were clean and the location of the hotel was great.
Just in the middle of everything...Museums, Restaurants, Public Transport and lots of Shops.
This hotel was recommended by friends and we are very greatfull they told us about the hotel Aalders.
We will return very soon.

author: BfromSC
segments: Beautiful Resort but Scuba Diving Not
Available - DIVERS READ!
We just returned from a nice visit to the Copamarina last week.
The grounds are beautiful, room was nice, and overall we had a good time.
The main issue we had was that scuba diving was not available all week.
When we checked in on Tuesday we were told that there would not be any diving available until Saturday, the day we were flying back to the US.
The hotel employee was very nice and said that May is a slow month so the scuba employees decided to take a job all week repairing a reef that had been badly damaged.
She said that we could go diving through a different dive shop that is 30 minutes away.
She did not say anything good about the shop, but simply said they do diving.
We would have to drive there or they could call us a cab.
My husband and I do not dive very often so we always research dive shops before we go diving with them.
We had already researched the Copamarina and felt very confident that this is a solid dive shop with a good reputation, however we did not know anything about the dive shop that is 30 minutes away.
We did not bring our laptop and the Copamarnia does not have any available computers, so we did not have a way to do any online research.
Therefore we decided not to go diving.

I guess we could have driven the 30 minutes and tried to find out more about the dive shop, but we had been stuck in horrible traffic in San Juan for 3 hours and simply did not want to get back in the car.
We came there expecting to dive onsite, not have to drive 30 minutes to a dive shop that may or may not be reputable.
If you are not a diver, I would recommend you stay at the Copamarina because it is very nice and peaceful.
We did not do the all inclusive meal plan, but I might consider it if we go back because there are not too many places nearby to eat.
I thought the food was good and we enjoyed the open air cafe and the music at night.
The only other issue we had is that you can hear everything in the room next door through the connecting locked door.
The first night we woke up at midnight because the people were talking and when they sneezed at 6:00 am it was so loud I thought someone was in our room.
I complained and was moved to a room that had a vacant room next door.
However, during high season this might not be possible.
The doors are very thin and need some insulation.
I guess the bottom line is that if you are a diver and plan to dive, I would not stay there.
Our experience is not isolated if you read the other reviews it happened to another reviewer in March of this year.
However, if you are simply wanting a nice vacation in relaxing area then the Copamarina is a good choice.
Feel free to email me with questions.

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: dont trust the staff here!
Although most of the reviews of this hotel tell a fairly accurate picture- central, basic.
attractive building, noisy and so on, we met an unexpected problem when we brought a group of 26 students.

Despite very careful bookings through our agent Studylink on arrival (late, with tired students) we found that the hotel had put us in rooms where students were expected to share beds- claiming that this was normal practice.
Basically the hotel had delibearatley overbooked and told us barefaced lies to cover up, knowing there was nothing we could do about it.

We had Spanish speakers with us but could do nothing- it was a take it or leave it attitude, and the same thing happened when some of our female staff were intimidated by german students in the room next door over the following days.
We got around the problem of rooms by moving beds and putting some students in another hotel, which was paid for eventually by Studylink, but it made an unpleasant start to the visit.
So don't trust the staff, and be prepared for them to try it on and cause problems.

author: melis330
segments: Great!! I really dont understand how people can have a bad experience with this hotel, the one thing that made it such a nice place was the staff, they are sooo friendly!!
The room was average size for amsterdam, the breakfast very nice, usual toast, ham, cheese, jam etc, and the place was very clean.
Im going back there this year and will definately stay there again.

author: Paul38
segments: Nice but not for western tourists.
This is not exactly a tourist hotel but it is clean and comfortable.
It has all the facilities of a 4 star hotel including a business centre, but beware they charge $17 for 30 minutes internet usage.
The hotel is located near Outram Park.
Taxis are readily available and the station is about a 10 minute walk away.
The rooms have a modern bathroom with shower, flat screen TV, a safe in the wardrobe, a mini-bar and tea/coffee making facilities.
The staff were polite and friendly.
As I said, it's not exactly a tourist hotel but then again Singapore isn't exactly the most thrilling place on earth either.

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: Marie celeste hotel!
Quite easy not to talk to a soul here.
It's cold , clinical, joyless.
Expect no warmth at all.Effectively its a posh office block...But great views and a delightful breakfast.
The parking is exorbitant, but drivers dont really have a choice.

author: politicallyincorrect
segments: Not the greatest
We are regular guests at various Embassy Suites and Hilton products.
While the location is great, this one is a bust.
The hotel is very dated and in need of a LOT of work.
Very noisy, not only within the hotel, but the construction noise (even on the weekend) early in the morning.
The bathrooms are very small and have plumbing problems.
Front doors of rooms are old, not very energy efficient or sound proofed.
The front desk staff could use a really good lesson on manners, professionalism, and genuine hospitality.
They could use a little polishing up and professional conversational skills.
The complimentary breakfast is great, and the staff in there is warm accomodating.
Manager's reception is kind of sad w/ plastic cups instead of glass.
The pool area is nice but the pool itself could use a good scrub down.
Slimey, dirty tiles.
Could be a real gem since it is an older property/building and could get some of it's original character back with some renovating, and better front desk staff.

author: lcsparkles
segments: You get what you pay for
My husband and I (both 30 years old) stayed at the Barcelo Dominican Beach from May 31 - June 7, 2008.
We booked through WestJet vacations and paid $1169 per person (taxes in) for the trip.
The hotel transfer was an additional $20 per person via the website.
The tourist card ($10 on entry) and departure tax ($20) was included in the WestJet vacation package.
The hotel is a 20 minute bus ride from the airport.
When we first checked in, we were given room 2403 (Block 2, 4th floor), which is right by the front desk.
There is a $20 deposit fee to use the safety box.
You get this money back at the end of your trip as long as you return the key.
Block 2 and 3 are in the same building and right behind the main entertainment area so it gets quite noisy for the shows from 9pm-11pm daily.
I would suggest anything in block 5 and up if you want less noise during those hours.

In the first 2 days we were moved to 4 different rooms because of various problems (original room's safety box was broken, then we asked to be moved to a more quiet section, then the new room they gave us wasn't made up and when no one came after 4 hours we went to the reception desk where they upgraded us to a Tropical Junior Suite for the all the inconvenience).
This made all the moving around worth it.
We had a jacuzzi in the room with a king sized bed and we were 10 steps away from the beach!
FOOD:There is only one main restaurant for buffet.
The food was mediocre and the selection is small (compared to other resorts we have been to).
The food was bascially the same day after day.
The Bahia (Brazilian) restaurant offers a mini buffet selection during lunch time.
There is a third buffet restaurant but it is in the Vera Club section (Italian folks) and I'm not even sure if we were allowed there, although we did not try.
The a la carte restaurants:You make reservations at the front podium in the main buffet area.
The only seating times available are 6pm or 8pm but if you show up after 9:30pm at any of the restaurants they will just seat you.
There was no limit on the amount of reservations you were allowed.
We made our reservations each day at 11am for the same evening with no problems.
Japanese restaurant - There is a grill at every table so the cook makes the food in front of you.
They cook up beef, chicken, seafood, cut up veggies and fried rice.
Each of the meats are cooked separately then combined with the veggies and then soy sauce is put on top.
The food comes out all tasting the same - just salty.
The dessert that is served is the same ones that come from the main buffet.
I could have done without this meal.
Brazilian - I would recommend this.
The food was simple but really good.
The meat on the skewers were delicious.
Mexican - This was okay.
Most of the items were deep fried.
I loved the chips and gucamole.
Italian - This was good.
The best part of the meal was the appetizers: meats, cheese, and the bread!!
I ordered filet mignon with a grape sauce but what I got was more of a salsbury steak with gravy.
24 hour snack bar - All they ever had was pizza and popcorn.
I saw hot dogs once or twice.
They don't have a menu posted so you have no idea what is even offered.
We ordered hamburgers once but the meat looked pink even after it was cooked twice.
Le Cafe - Great!!
They have fantastic frappucinos - topped with whipped cream and drizzled in chocolate sauce...mmmm!
MISCBeach - Ocean/beach itself is beautiful.
Resort does not take care of its beach though.
There was garbage (straws, cigarette butts, cups, broken glass) all over the place.
No garbage cans to be seen around the beach.
I never saw anyone walking around picking up garbage either.
Massages - Massage huts all over the resort.
These are outdoor and in the open but there is a semi private hut near the 24 hour snack bar.
They charge $30 an hour and it is worth it.
We tipped $5 per person.
The resort spa is separate building and they charge a lot more.

Things to bring (aside from the obvious) - Antibacterial hand soap for your room, spray air freshner, an alarm clock (or just a clock as they do no have them in any of the rooms), Cortizone (for heat rashes), Benadryl (to stop the itching from heat rash...lol), face cloths (we got these one day and never saw them again).
We brought mosquito repellant and After Bite but did not see a real need to use this.
We did however get some anti-Malaria pills from our doctor as there have been some outbreaks in the Punta Cana area this year.
Tipping - We tipped the maids $2 each day, $2 at the a la carte restaurants, and $2 per bag to the bell boys as they dragged our suitcases up 4 floors when we first got there.
We did not frequent the bars so did not tip when we went up for the odd drink.
Over-all the trip was okay but a little disappointing.
We did not go on vacation to party and get drunk all the time.
It was more to relax, enjoy the beach, and have some decent food.
Personally I would not go back to a Barcelo resort.
I have found that the Occidental Grand and Bahia Principe chains to be much better.
We normally go around this time every year and pay about $1500....so I guess you get what you pay for!

author: mistralj
segments: Fantastic Hotel The
Russell hotel is an older hotel with a certain charm to it.
The location is the best thing about this hotel - only minutes from Circular Quay, close to the Opera House and steps from great restaurants and cafes.
The staff are extremely friendly and helpfull, ready to help with anything, especially your bags, there is no elevator (heritage building).
The rooms are small but very cozy, we would definitely stay here again.

author: ShaluKalu
segments: I will stay at the
Donatello again The rooms at the Donatello are comfortable, practical, and attractive.
The staff is helpful and pleasant.
Breakfast is a buffet continental repast--the room gets crowded but the food is quite fresh.
I was there for 12 nights and don't have a single criticism of the hotel, except for the crowded breakfast room.
The restaurant attached to the hotel, however, is quite mediocre and very noisy, with unresponsive staff.
Avoid it.

author: curiousinleeds
segments: Brilliant Hotel - would recommend to anyone
We have just returned from a very pleasant 3 night stay at the Jolly Carlton in Amsterdam during the period between Christmas and New Year.
We thoroughly enjoyed our stay.
The staff were very polite, friendly and couldn't do enough for you.
The room was more than adequate for our needs.
It was clean and tidy and as there was a thermostat in the room, the temperature was just right.
We were on the 7th floor so noise was not a problem.
There was a big choice at breakfast and again the staff were very friendly and quick to take your order for hot drinks and the made to order omelettes, scrambled eggs etc.
The hotel was in a perfect location to explore all the sights in Amsterdam.
It was just over 5 minutes walk to Dam Square and a couple of minutes away from Rembrantplein where there were lots of bars, clubs and restaurants.
I will definitely stay that this hotel on our next trip to Amsterdam.

author: chomporn
segments: You have to confirm your reservation!
I chose the Francisco Bay because it locates near the Fisherman warf with free parking space, and affordable price.
I have made reservation through hotels.
com and already paid for the whole cost with email confirming my reservation.
At the time I checked in, the fron desks said we don't have your reservation and there is no room available!!
They said this problem can normally happen and just sent us to the other hotel with the same owner but was much more far away (quite not responsible).
They said I shouldn't have any problem with the distance since San Fran is a very small city, you can take the bus around.
I think that is not their business to judge!
I have read from the review that there was this kind of problem before but didn't think this should happen oftenly.
I think they might intentionally give my room to the other with higher rates.
So if you make a reservation through internet, you have to call them and confirm it!

author: brandenburg5
segments: a tale of good and bad

Positives: gorgeous landscaped grounds in the midst of the paddy fields; beautiful villas; wonderful breakfasts (the home-made bread with home-made jam was delicious); extras such as free mini-bar, free laundry and transfers into town (15-minute drive); lovely spa; fantastic infinity poolNegatives: internet never worked and staff didn't understand why it wasn't acceptable that 50% of websites (including all online newspapers) were blocked by their server; extremely high prices in the restaurant (why should main courses be 2-3 times as expensive as very chic restaurants in Seminyak?);

the butler who was a kind of concierge, and was very pushy in getting us to book excursions from which the hotel was clearly making money - this butler often made us very uncomfortable, and was not knowledgeable about Bali and gave us very poor advice which wasted our time and money.

Ubud itself has a lot to offer, great shopping and sightseeing and restaurants, but does get very over-crowded and in the daytime is simply a massive traffic jam.All in all, the Chedi would be great if you truly need to get away from it all - staying in your villa, lounging by the pool, eating fine meals (at a huge mark-up but probably still cheaper than London or New York).
But the atmosphere is soul-less.
You almost never see anyone else (apart from your butler who constantly comes to your door - even entering once without knocking!),

and bizarrely there often wasn't anyone at reception which is a bit of a shock when you return to the hotel and need to get your key.Very strange, and ultimately not very pleasant despite all its positives.

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: Enjoyed the Stay
My wife and I have spent 5 nights in October, (They really party on Halloween there!!),
and enjoyed every day.
The hotel is a few blocks removed from the noise and activity of Waikiki, so things are a little quieter.
Our room was an oceanview standard with King bed on the 12th floor.
Not much view as it's almost 2 blocks from beach.
Quiet for the most part, the room was adequate but could use some minor remodeling.
The restaurant was expensive so we ate locally at more moderately priced restaurants, of which there are many within easy walking distance.
We would definately stay again.
Moderate pricing and quiet location with parking, (Fee $9 to $12), yet still close to the Waikiki scene made it a good choice for us.

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: We were not in Paradise
Our stay in Hotel Paradisus for 8 nights has not been good.
The price we paid and the service provided us has not been of 5*****Quality and the reason are:Transportation to the hotel was very confusing.
No welcome drink or greeting upon arrival.
We saw it later with other arrivals.
Room serviceRoom service needs management.
Not enough towels or sometimes nothing until 6pm.
Bed linen was for a queen size bed.
We had a king size bed!!
Most of the time we got no bottle water for cleaning the teeeth or drinking.
No colorful bed spread.
The brochure and the webside looks fantastic but none of them was there.
No extra bedding for the night because it was sometimes cool.
Too much noise from other ruede guests with no manner which came home between 4am and 5am in the morning and talked for one hour in front of their room.
We asked for another room, no answer.
Asked for another mattress because it was like you are sleeping on a stone.
We called to the front desk and got promised they will change it, nothing was happen during our stay.
Sofas in room were dirty and damaged.
Bathtop curtain was to short and the bathroom was allways flooded after taking a shower.
Food serviceFrench Gourmet - nice presentation but no seasoning, very bland and no taste.
Sakura Japanese Restaurant - the cook was from the Dom. Republic.
Needs no explaination.
Palapa Grill Seafood Restaurant - Grilled fish overcooked, dry and fishy.
Lunch Buffet - not enough selection.
Quality was not very special and no flavour.
Nobody knew what's in the chafing dishes or on all the plate, because no labelling.
Dolce Vita Italian Restaurant - some of the dishes were good.
We never tried the mexican restaurant or the brazilBeverage ServiceFront Lobby bar - Very good in the night.
Excellent bartenders.
Beach Bar - very slowBar by Hibiscus Restaurant - very unfriendly and bad set up not guest friendly.
We found only 4 bars and missing the other 3 which we read on the webside.
Waitersfriendly but 70% spoke no english and was sometimes difficult to get the right thing.
Head waiters from the restaurants to take the order mostly unfriendly - no smile.
The landscaping was very beautiful and well groomed.
All restrooms in Restaurants were nice and cleanIn all we paid for a 5*****Hotel and got 3*** Service.
We are very dissapointed.
We heard so many complaining during our stay and hope the took some time too to let them know.
We were blinded with the wonderful brochure and the webside about this Hotel Paradisus.
We travelled all over the world and had never such a bad experience.
Two very dissapointed world traveller.
BH

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: Wouldn't Hesitate to Return
Reservations were made via call to Personalities Hotels- all went off without a hitch.
$85 + parking was better than I was expecting.
Directions from the hotel website were right on, check-in was completed in 30 seconds for a weekend stay.
For those concerned about the neighborhood- it's SF, get over panhandlers.
Why pay more to be a block closer to Union Square?
I wouldn't!
Our corner room doubled as a fire escape, which allowed opening the window for fresh air.
We were on 8th floor, so very little street noise- asked to be away from kids!
The room itself was small, but no smaller than other large city hotels- if you want room to walk, I'd suggest taking the F down to Ferry Plaza.
If ever I returm.
I'll certainly check rates at this and other hotels under same ownership.
If I was expecting the Hyatt, I'd have been disappointed, but, for someone who travels extensively for work, this beats many chains hands-down!

author: annbury
segments: Pet Friendly Find in SF
We chose the Laurel Inn because it takes pets and provides parking, but found that it has a lot more going for it.
The location in a quiet residential neighborhood was great for us, as it gives a different view of SF than the usual downtown one, but it could be inconvenient for some travellers.
The rooms were unusually large for a city hotel, and very comfortable, with a pleasant and muted W-ish decor.
Our first room had a small kitchenette, the second did not -- here, a micro wave and a small fridge would have been welcome.
The front desk staff was very helpful and very welcoming, to us and to our standard poodle.
The parking was great.
And the price was very reasonable, considering the quality of the place.
We would recommend the Laurel enthusiastically to our friends, unless they need to be downtown.

author: KOE-KTO
segments: OK hotel Stayed 2 nights.
Pros: location, clean large room.
Cons: free internet only in the business center which has only 2 computers with a sign (15 minutes per guest only).
No pool, no sauna, no whirlpool.

author: CT-Travler
segments: Overall a good experience
Stayed here about 3 times in the past four years.
Used to stay at the Boston Park Plaza Hotel and Towers but when the rates when up found the Radisson online and it is right around the corner from the Boston Park Plaza.
GREAT LOCATION: Close to the theatre district, Boston Common, Newberry Street, and the Long Wharf area.
The rooms are big and are fairly priced for a Boston hotel.
Only compaints are that the service is a little slow during busy times and during one of my stays there were three or four tiny ants on the floor.

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: Like dating a supermodel...
Yes, this is a beautiful hotel, but aside from that there is nothing.
Service: abysmal (you are supposed to be assigned a peronal assistant to cater to your every whim...I got a phone number which was always busy and a front desk that could care less).
Noise: Constant (until 4AM, front desk unapologietic, room on 3rd floor as if on the dancefloor).
Room: Large, well furnished and stylish, but the sink, toilet and bath all overflowed.
Management was receptive to comments upon check out, but acknowledged that the hotel was having trouble with staffing/noise/growing pains.
In the end, not even close to worth it.

author: cruisermeg
segments: Pool closed, lobby torn apart and the owners
Refuse to notify guests!
I was supposed to stay at this hotel on Canal Street for 3 nights at the end of June using a coupon for one of them.
Arrived in N.O. La via Amtrak.
I was advised to take a taxi to the hotel rather than the bus as, since Katrina, the buses in the area of the train station/arena/Superdome are irregular.

There isn't much in the train station, but there is a Subway restaurant, some sort of coffee shop (which may be attached to the Subway), a small gift shop and both Amtrak and Greyhound ticket counters.
A few police/sheriff's officers were present, and very polite and helpful in providing taxi info.
My cab driver had just gotten his tax the day before.
He lost everything in the storm.
Very nice man.
I can't believe that people in FEMA trailers have to pay rent on the space for the trailer.
Don't get me started.
Back to the hotel.
Cabs to the hotels are a flat $11.00 (which includes a $1.00 fuel surcharge).
Canal Street is under repair, as is much of the city, even two years after Katrina.
Mostly the sidewalks are being rebuilt.
I didn't have a problem with the construction in the city and I came down mainly because NOLa needs support.
Upon arrival at the Marriott, I knew things were not going to be so swell.
First, there were two uniformed associates outside, a doorman and a bellman.
While one opened my door, neither of them got my bags out of the cab, nor did they offer a single female assistance into the hotel.
Strike one.
Upon entering, the entire lobby is under construction, so you have to lug your stuff up an escalator to the temporary lobby on the second floor.
Let me explain.
I have no problem with renovations.
BUT, this hotel made NO mention of any renovations on their website.
I checked and double checked, and called Marriott's Platinum desk and asked them to verify that no mention was made.
There was nothing.I checked in.
Actually, I was one day early but since the hotel was about 17% occupied, it wasn't a problem.
I was given a room in the river tower with a view of the other tower and pool.
The pools are closed for repair.
Again, I was not informed of this in advance, nor at check-in!
The Concierge lounge, access to which I receive due to my frequency of Marriott-branded use, was across the hotel resulting in a trip down the elevator, across the lobby and back up.
Oh well.A side note about the elevators.
Marriott seems to be adding fancy, high speed elevators to it's large hotels.
The first I saw this was at the Marriott Marquis in NYC.
You enter your desired floor on the keypad OUTSIDE the elevator.
Then, the display returns the number/letter of the car which will take you to your floor.
So, make sure you pay attention!
Back to the hotel.
The room was small with no view.
The room was very noisy.
I was told that all windows are being replaced with double-paned glass.
Honestly, you can hear people whistling at other people on the street.
Also, construction on the street starts at about 6:30 AM so forget about sleeping in.
Again, I was up early and I don't have a problem with rebuilding.
I took a walk through the hotel.
Frankly, most of the associates didn't acknowledge anyone's presence.
The sole person who convinced me to not leave was one of the security guards.
She took it upon herself to escort me to the front desk for a room change.

I was informed by several associates and managers that the owners of the hotel (it is my understanding that Marriott owns the people but others own the building) refused to inform guests of the renovations.
This is inconceivable, especially given that the rate was $30 more per night than at the JW Marriott across the street and that property is completely renovated!
I was upgraded to a two room suite.
Actually a standard room with a connecting door into a parlor room.
The living space was quite nice.
I had two bathrooms, a dining area, couch, wet bar and there is a Murphy bed in the living room so I suppose it would be great for families, or to sell if the place is sold out.
Not likely any time soon.
The food and service in the concierge lounge wasn't great.
OK, the first night, everything was seafood which I don't eat.
Others may love it.
There were mini crab cakes, shrimp and a big pot of gumbo.
Problem is, the fishy smell overpowered the lounge, and the elevator landing outside.
Fish shouldn't smell fishy or like garbage.
It shouldn't really smell at all.
Yuck!
Also, for breakfast, the food was OK but there were no English Muffins, minimal pastries and cereals and just not a big selection.
It looked nice, whatever there was of it.
However, when I went to get butter balls for my toast, a piece of glass about 1 inch square was commingled with the butter and landed on my toast.
I had to go into the little kitchen to find someone to show.
Her response was, oh Ill take care of it.
Not I'm sorry or some other words of concern, just Oh.
Needless to say, breakfast that day, and each subsequent day was cafe au lait and beignets at Cafe du Monde.
YUM!
The restaurant is temporarily located on the 41st floor in what was the fine-dining restaurant pre-Katrina.
There are a couple sandwiches, some entrees including fish and steak, and appetizers.
But, dessert-wise, they had cheesecake, chocolate cake and ice cream.
Come on.
I know it's slow, but this is NOLa, can we at least have bread pudding or something yummy?
The turkey club was good, albeit served just on run-of-the-mill white bread, not the advertised sourdough.
When I saw that on the bar menu the second night, I asked the bartender.
She said never in 20 years has it been on sourdough!
Prices in the restaurant were reasonable for New Orleans.
Typical hotel prices, although room service is around $2.00 per item more than the dining room, plus a 21% service charge and tax.
That's a little too much if you ask me.Overall, the city is still almost empty which is a shame.
I haven't been here for some 20 years and I don't recall too much.
The French Quarter is indecent shape but there are a lot of vacant buildings.
Also, while I remember lots of bars, I didn't remember seeing as many of the, hmm, adult-type places as I did this time.
In conclusion, New Orleans needs support.
It still can be a charming city again and I am sure that new developments (I saw a big TRUMP banner on the cab ride over) will help.
y problems weren't with the city.
Most of the people I encountered outside of the hotel were very nice.
80% of the people IN the hotel couldn't care less about whether guests are there.
I wanted to shout.
.I came here to support the city, can you at least PRETEND you are glad I am here??

When I went to the desk to hand in my certificate, both the associate and manager told me I had to call in advance and that the certificate (a print out from the Marriott Rewards Platinum page that says PRINT THIS PAGE AND SURRENDER) was no good since it wasn't the certificate.
Frankly I still don't know what they were saying, aside from implying that I am an idiot.
So, after only 2 nights, I lugged my stuff down the escalator with no help, across the street and checked into the JW a day early.
We shall see how THAT goes.I won鈥檛 return to the Marriott and I suggest they get their act together and inform people of the renovations.
Out of all the associates I encountered, only two-a female security guard and the aforementioned bartender, were nice.

author: waggy
segments: Excellent Hotel Lovely hotel,quiet location just off la Ramblas.
Efficient and friendly staff.
Spotlessly clean.

Watch out for the pickpockets, and gypsies carrying babies !They will put a newspaper on the table and pick up anything under it !!! Dont get caught on the pea under the cup trick ! Its a big scam by an organised gang.
The only winners are part of the gang themselves !!

author: kelly257
segments: wonderful wedding my husband and i had planned to get married abroad.
when we saw secrets excellence at punta cana we instantly fell in love.
we paid extra for the wedding package, room upgrade and the excellence club, it was money well spent.
the hotel, and its staff were brilliant and could not do enough for you.
as we had paid for the excellence club we were whisked away on arrival and taken to an air- conditioned room ( which we both welcomed being from Scotland) and were given a glass of bubbly.
this was a lovely start to the holiday.
as for the wedding we met the wedding co-ordinator, Iveilesse, the following day and she covered every aspect of the wedding planning and more!
we took our parent with us and we all truly relaxed and enjoyed every moment.
the staff cant do enough for you and are so polite.
make sure you have plenty of $1 bills or 50/100 peso notes the really do deserve their tips.
the hotel and the rooms were imaculate. ohh and what a room.
the bed is enormus and the jacuzzi you can both lie out in at the same time.i cant say how great a time we had just go and enjoy every moment.
it was that good were are going to book into one of the other secret resorts for next summer!!!

author: A TripAdvisor Member
segments: Efficient, No frills

Decided at 1am one night to visit Paris for a couple of days, searched and booked 10hrs later through boookings, finding a room ready and just sufficient to sleep a family of 4 with 2 children under 5 a few hours later.
Even though the initial request for extra bedding wasn't made very clearly we were accommodated and looked after properly.
Should you be driving: Reasonably well located, near to the outer peripheral road (just watch out which exit you take from Place de Nation...).
Parking at the park house Picpus recommended (10min walk away from hotel).

author: CtChris
segments: Could have done better
The hotel itself was interesting since it is 'round', the staff were polite but the hotel itself is understaffed.
The breakfast was yukky.
Although the rooms (suites) are a nice size, the decor was marginal-i.
e. wall paper coming off walls, bathtub stained, shade pulls very dirty, stained bedspead and cruddy/filthy windows.
The price was ok but after staying-I would expect that the rates should be lowered.
The neighborhood was marginal...must not be far from a landfill-the stink was terrible!
Don't let the price fool you-it's better to spend a few extra bucks for cleanliness, a walkable neighborhood without someone asking you for money or cigarettes or whatever they may be looking for.

The dead mouse outside the front door didn't help-nor did the refuse container outside the front door (it was not emptied the entire time we were there-overfull with food, butts, styrofoam cups, etc and smelled horrible).
I wish the staff well but the rest of it was terrible.
Never again.

author: worldtravellor12345
segments: Great owners, service, location
Just got back from our vacation in Italy in which we stayed three nights at this hotel.
We paid 118 Euro a night for a double room in this hotel and were pleased.
It's right down the block from the train station, which is very helpful for lugging your luggage.
The room was fine.
Nothing special, but it was clean, big enough for two and decent private bathroom.
The breakfast was good - cake, bread, cereal, OJ and coffees.
The owners and receptionists spoke English and were very, very nice and accommodating - helped us with directions and book reservations at museums, etc.
Internet was one euro every 15 minutes.
Location is not bustling - but it is close to everything.
